etymologies: early 17th century (in an earlier sense). From Middle French, French bonifier to make better, improve, to do good to, to give a bonus to from Italian bonificare to make better, improve (especially land), to give a bonus to from post-classical Latin bonificare to improve, to benefit from bonificus (attested in a glossary), alteration (after classical Latin bonus good) of classical Latin beneficus; compare -fy

definitions: To make (something, especially that which is bad or unsatisfactory) good or better; to improve.
